title: Mimo & Yuyu
statementHtml:
Mimo and Yuyu just finished their 1000-piece jigsaw puzzle of beautiful Bellas Artes! Now they are looking for other ways to entertain themselves.

There is an n×mn×m grid of cells with columns labeled 1,2,…m1,2,…m from left to right and rows labeled 1,2,…n1,2,…n from top to bottom. Let (u,v)(u,v) (1≤u≤n,1≤v≤m1≤u≤n,1≤v≤m) denote the cell in the uu-th row and vv-th column. Each cell can contain any number of tokens which are indistinguishable among themselves. Initially, there are kk tokens, the ii-th of which is located in (xi,yi)(xi,yi).

Mimo and Yuyu now play a game alternating turns. On his/her turn, a player chooses a token cc currently in the grid as well as a sequence of distinct cells (a1,b1),(a2,b2),…(ap,bp)(a1,b1),(a2,b2),…(ap,bp) (p≥2p≥2) such that the following conditions hold:

Then, he/she removes cc from the grid and adds 1 token to (a2,b2),(a3,b3),…(ap,bp)(a2,b2),(a3,b3),…(ap,bp) each. This concludes his/her turn.

The player who cannot make a turn loses. Mimo goes first. Determine who will win if both players play optimally.

For example, consider a game where n=6n=6, m=4m=4, and 3 tokens currently exist in (2,3)(2,3), (4,2)(4,2), and (6,4)(6,4) (as shown in Figure 1). In this scenario, a valid turn, for instance, could consist of choosing cc as the token in (6,4)(6,4) and the sequence of cells with p=10p=10 defined by a=[6,6,5,4,3,2,2,3,4,4]a=[6,6,5,4,3,2,2,3,4,4] and b=[4,3,3,3,3,3,2,2,2,1]b=[4,3,3,3,3,3,2,2,2,1]. Note that (ai,bi)(ai,bi) describes valid cells in the grid.

For the sake of clarity, a dashed line is shown in Figure 2 passing through this particular choice of (a1,b1),(a2,b2),…(ap,bp)(a1,b1),(a2,b2),…(ap,bp) in order. Figure 3 and 4 show the state of the game after the turn is performed, with and without the highlighted sequence respectively.

Note that the first and seventh test case in the example correspond to the games shown in Figure 1 and Figure 4 respectively.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains three integers nn, mm, and kk (1≤n,m,k≤2⋅1051≤n,m,k≤2⋅105).

The ii-th of the next kk lines contains two integers xixi and yiyi (1≤xi≤n,1≤yi≤m1≤xi≤n,1≤yi≤m).

It is guaranteed that the sum of kk over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.

Note that there is no explicit upper bound on the sum of nn and mm.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output Mimo if Mimo wins, or Yuyu if Yuyu wins.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings mIMo, mimo, Mimo, and MIMO will be recognized as responses indicating that the first player wins.
noteHtml:
In the second test case, Mimo cannot make any moves, so Yuyu wins.

In the third test case, the token in (1,1)(1,1) cannot be used as cc for any turn because there is no sequence of cells that begins with (1,1)(1,1) and satisfies b1>b2b1>b2, so the game might unfold as follows:

  • Mimo removes the token in (1,2)(1,2) and adds a token to (1,1)(1,1).
  • Yuyu removes the token in (2,2)(2,2) and adds a token to (2,1)(2,1).
  • Mimo removes the token in (3,2)(3,2) and adds a token to (3,1)(3,1).

It can be shown that Yuyu could not have played more optimally, so Mimo wins.
